title: 106_s1468
content: The Act is titled the "United States Capitol Visitor Center Commemorative Coin Act of 1999". It includes findings related to the Act. Congress finds that the Capitol building in Washington, D.C. is a significant symbol of democracy, attracting millions of visitors annually. The building lacks necessary facilities for visitors, but has excellent security provided by the United States Capitol Police. Congress has allocated $100,000,000 for improvements. Congress has allocated $100,000,000, supplemented with private funds, to construct a Capitol Visitor Center for high security and visitor education. Congress invites voluntary fundraising participation and authorizes coins commemorating the first Congress convening in the Capitol building. The Capitol Visitor Center is being constructed with funds from Congress and private donations. Coins commemorating the first Congress convening in the Capitol building will be authorized to raise additional funds for the United States Capitol Preservation Commission. Coins commemorating the first Congress convening in the Capitol building will be authorized to raise additional funds for the United States Capitol Preservation Commission, including specifications for the coins. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury may mint and issue bimetallic $10 coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific specifications, including weight, diameter, and composition. If bimetallic coins are not feasible, $5 gold coins weighing 8.359 grams may be minted instead. The Secretary may mint and issue up to 100,000 $5 gold coins weighing 8.359 grams, with a diameter of 0.850 inches and containing 90% gold and 10% alloy. Mintage levels specified in subsection (a) can be waived. The coins minted under this Act are legal tender. The Secretary shall obtain platinum, gold, and silver from available sources for minting coins under this Act. The design of coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the first meeting of the United States Congress in the Capitol Building, with inscriptions including the coin's value, year "2000", and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design for these coins will be selected accordingly. The design for coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the United States Capitol Preservation Commission, the Commission of Fine Arts, and the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The Secretary will issue coins in consultation with various committees. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single United States Mint facility. These coins will be the first commemorative coins with the year "2000" inscription. The Secretary will consult with the Commission for promotion, advertising, and marketing. The Secretary may enter into a contract with the Commission or a designated entity for promoting and marketing the coins minted under this Act to boost sales. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, the surcharge provided in subsection (d), and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted before the coins are issued. Prepaid orders for coins minted under this Act will be accepted by the Secretary before issuance, with sale prices at a reasonable discount. Sales will include a surcharge established by the Secretary, ranging from $3 to $50 per coin depending on the denomination. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales will be deposited in the Capitol Preservation Fund for the construction and maintenance of a Capitol Visitor Center.
